content: For validator 4, how do you differentiate between "i" as a word and the "i" in "first"?

Comment: I approved this contribution.
This puzzle offers a unique challenge that I haven't encountered elsewhere. Everything is clearly presented with a well-crafted introduction to the challenge. The tests are thorough and accurate. Overall, it's a solid and enjoyable challenge. It might be a little tricky to be an easy challenge (in Java, it's always a mess to manipulate characters), but it's acceptable.
So cool !
Great puzzle
Great

I've put a lot of thought into this and I think this puzzle is just too similar to the following:

https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/caesar-is-the-chief

Sure, you can point out some minor differences, but the algorithm to solve each puzzle is always going to be extremely similar.

My suggestion is to eliminate Mission 1 and have a 4 part series.

Comment: This puzzle is great and very clear, and even funny !
I validate it because I think it should be accessible to everyone, not just as a beta.
I hope there wille be some more missions for Agent X soon !

This puzzle is great !

The wording is complete, the test set pertinent and I really enjoyed it...
It looks pretty cool to solve, gratz for the job done !
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Nice job! Do you want to try to use the words ciphertext and plaintext here as you have done in later puzzles?

Test Case Design: I found a couple validators to be quite a bit harder than the corresponding test case.

Test Case 1 - no wrapping in the encoding of the word
Validator 1 - 100% wrapping in the encoding of the word

I suggest adding a test case and validator (or even two TC/Val combos) between TC/Val 1 and TC/Val 2. By doing that you can have no wrapping in TC 1 and Val 1 and then you can have wrapping in TC 2/Val 2. You might even consider adding another test case where the encoding the word involves both wrapping and not wrapping.

Test Case 2 / Validator 2 - I found the validator to be harder than the test case. The test case is about as easy as you can make it with the word matching the first letter of the message and using a space as the separator. In the validator, we have to check both sides of the word and we have to make sure to check all separators. I would like to see more test cases/validators that test all the following:

1) word matches very beginning of message
2) word is found in the middle of the message
3) word matches the very end of the message

I don't think you need to say anything about this in your Goal, but I think it's important to test that the solutions properly consider the beginning and the end of the message as implied word separators.

Overall, I really like your idea and I especially like your multi-puzzle idea exploring other techniques using the same structure. I personally like when an author uses a significant number of test cases to try to cover all edge cases.

By the way, I watched "The Imitation Game" last night.
Really cool puzzle! Looking forward to solving it.
I tried to incorporate a story into the visible test.

This looks like a slightly harder version of an existing puzzle: https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/caesar-is-the-chief

Goal
* Please change "The Caesar code (etc up to the end)" to:

The Caesar cipher works by substituting each letter in the original message by another letter a fixed number of positions (called the [[key]]) down the alphabet, returning to the beginning of the alphabet after reaching {{z}}. [[key]] is non-negative in this puzzle.

For example, with a [[key]] of {{3}}:
- {{a}} becomes {{d}}
- {{w}} becomes {{z}}
- {{x}} becomes {{a}}

The encrypted message contains both lowercase and uppercase letters, and the original case should be kept in the decrypted message.

Non-letter characters should be kept unchanged.

Output
* Please change "The decode message" to "The decrypted message" (the same term you used in Input section).

Constraints
* Please change "Len" to "Length".

* Please delete the first constraint.

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement, e.g. "write key and decoded message".

Cover picture
* Suggest to upload a cover picture for the puzzle.

Title
* It's a bit weird to have "Episode 1" at the beginning of the title. Maybe add a series title before "Episode 1" (though the part after "Episode 1" may have to be shortened)?

For your reference, I've searched the existing multi-part puzzles and found the following:
â€¢ Binary neural network - Part 1
â€¢ Binary neural network - Part 2
â€¢ Derivative time !!! - part1
â€¢ Derivative time !!! - part2
â€¢ Is the King In Check? (Part 1)
â€¢ Is the King In Check? (Part 2)
â€¢ The hungry duck - part 1
â€¢ The hungry duck - part 2

Thanks.

UPDATED
FYI: My code that was previously 100% now fails test case 15. This is why I like lots of test cases and an attempt to cover all edge cases.

Not sure if I get your meaning correctly, but to make the puzzle a bit more challenging, you may try to introduce a Caesar cipher with multiple keys, e.g.

1st, 4th, 7th, â€¦ characters in each word: key = 5
2nd, 5th, 8th, â€¦ character in each word: key = 8
3rd, 6th, 9th, â€¦ character in each word: key = 10

Also, your current solution may be wrong because this line:

if word in decode_message:

doesn't take into account whether word is indeed a separate word or not. For example, if the guaranteed word is "chief", and one of the words in the decoded message is "handkerchief", they'll still match.

So, even if after further thought you don't want to make the puzzle harder, you still have to fix this issue and add more cases to cover such a scenario.

Hope this helps!
Thanks again, i changed a bit the principe to make this different what do you think of this now ?

It's a good variation.

* The explanation in the middle two paragraphs become invalid because they're talking about letters and the alphabet only, instead of the range of extended characters covered now. Please update those two paragraphs.

* I don't think character 127 should be included in the cipher, because it is not a printable character. Please change 127 to 126 instead. Then in the example, "~" will become a double quotation mark instead.

* In Goal section, please define "SP" by changing "SP" to "SP (space character)".

* As I mentioned last time, please add more cases to cover a scenario such as "chief" / "handkerchief".

* I see that you've used different titles for Episode 1 and Episode 2. That'll make searching difficult, as not all people realise they belong to the same series.

Thanks.
Updated, what do you think of the title ?

Goal
* Please change the middle two paragraphs as follows:

The Caesar cipher used by Agent X works by substituting each character in the original message by another character a fixed number of positions (called the [[key]]) down the ASCII code range of {{32}} to {{126}} on a wrap-around basis. [[key]] is non-negative in this puzzle.

Title
* I like this revised title! For easier searching and identification, please change the title to "Agent X Mission 1 â€” The Caesar Cipher".

Cases
* As I mentioned last time, please add more cases to cover a scenario such as "chief" / "handkerchief".

Thanks.

I don't think "i" is a good [[word]] to use, because there's more than one possible solution. There are more than one one-letter words in both cases.
Yes but space is substituted to, that make the good solution only when the message is fully decrypted. In all possible substitution only this one work

In the test, why can't the solution be:
z1$vtvz(v1+!'=1yr(v1+!'1w!' u1&yv1&$rtv%1!w1rxv &1i?

The second last character can also be translated to "i".
Yes, but it's not surrounded by separating characters.

OK, I get your point.

Please move the second constraint to Goal section, because that's a requirement of the puzzle. A constraint is one that imposes a limitation on the possible range of cases that a player should handle.
Ok thank you

The random input strings make the puzzle much less appealing. I'd really like to see all the test strings tell an interesting story.

(I'd go so far to extend that to validator strings tooâ€¦ but as they can't be seen except in contribution view, I won't suggest the extension.)

What do you think of adding another test case, telling i hear some interference of something like that before the random message ?

Because, I think they are needed (you can refer to Timinator last respond)

While you can add another test case if you want, my point is that it is better for the **visible** test cases to have interesting output (story) lines. So, at a minimum, I'd like to see the Random tests 1, 2 and 3 be changed from random characters to something meaningful and story-relevant. ðŸ˜‰
And of course, more test cases the better to cover the different scenarios (including edge cases), as mentioned by Timinator and also encouraged as per the contribution guidelines.
Look's better now ?

Yes, it's better, though I'll leave @Timinator and others to review whether they cover the edge cases adequately.

Also it's better for Test 6 and Test 7 to have different names for easier referencing when needed.

Thanks!
